story:
We are ready to launch the Botanical Springs Evolution Academy, but we need your help!

Bee populations are dramatically declining worldwide and Botanical Springs, LLC. decided we needed to do something about it.  That is why we started a new division, the Evolution Academy, dedicated to combating this decline by spreading our passion for bees and beekeeping.  So please donate and join the Evolution Revolution!

We've found an incredible bus formerly used as a mobile police command center. Now, we need funds to transform the bus into a mobile classroom to continue its public service,  complete with active display hives and beekeeping equipment. Once completed, we will be able to bring our bees safely to schools, youth organizations, and garden clubs throughout New England where children and adults alike will have the opportunity to learn valuable life-skills while engaging in fun, hands-on activities developed in conjunction with Bill Cumming, Director of the Boothby Institute and a leader in the field of alternative education.  These activities have been designed to increase both self-awareness and environmental awareness.  

Our back to nature approach can be tailored to a wide variety of programs and fit a diverse set of subjects from math to biology.  At the same time, we will train people to build their own bee hives, plant pollinator friendly gardens, and start compost bins to increase the productivity of their gardens. This Fall and early Spring, our mobile classroom will be hitting the road, inviting guests to learn about maple and birch tree tapping.  The time old tradition of sugaring is currently undergoing its own evolution, affording us the perfect forum to offer additional hands-on learning activities highlighting math, science, and entrepreneurship  with simple experiments geared around tap-size, evaporator use, and advancements in reverse osmosis technology to name just a few.  Botanical Springs will go to your location, identify the ideal trees for tapping, and teach you how to effectively and efficiently tap your own trees.  In addition, guests are invited to take part in tree tapping activities on our land outside of Portland, Maine. We believe this is a perfect vehicle to engage and empower individuals, fostering new family fun and traditions.

Our expert tappers / culinary experts are raising the bar for both sap-based beverages and education.  Our birch drinks won first and second place at the recent International Birch Sap and Syrup Conference tasting co-hosted by Paul Smith College and Cornell University's Cooperative Extension.  We want nothing more than to share our expertise and passion through the Evolution Academy.



 

Once up and running (anticipated Spring 2016), groups will be invited to visit the Botanical Springs Apiary and Campground just outside Portland, Maine to experience first-hand how beekeeping enhances the overall health of a woodland farm.  Here, we offer orienteering  team-building activities designed to meet your organization’s unique needs.  Guests will be able to participate in exciting learning activities at our nature classroom constructed from recycled cargo containers and set amid miles of bucolic hiking trails. 

Lastly, but certainly not least,  the Evolution Academy will allow Botanical Springs to expand our research into to increase understanding of hive loss, its multiple causes, and potential solutions.


We appreciate any and all contributions, whether financial or simply a Facebook "Like." Everything will help pollinate our Evolution Academy! 

What We Need:

There's a lot of work that needs to go into transforming our bus into a mobile classroom as well as launching our Apiary classroom in Maine.  We've got no shortage of elbow grease, but some items just need to be purchased.  

List of items / renovations for the Mobile Classroom including cost estimates:

  1. Custom Wrap for the Bus: $1500

  2. Folding Tables :  5 x $150 = $750

  3. Folding Chairs: 50 x $25 = $1250

  4. Restoration of the bus for proper bathroom, sink use, storage: $6000

  5. Custom-built display hive:  $3,000


List of items of for fixed classroom in Maine:

  1. Solar panels:  $3700

  2. Shipping container:  $10,000

  3. Complete beekeeper suits:  12 x $250  = $3000

  4. Honey extractor:  3 x $625 = $1875


                                                                                             Total:  $31,075

                                     

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Although we need funds to get the Botanical Springs Evolution Academy and Mobile Classroom rolling, there are other ways you can help.  We are always looking for volunteers in the New England area.  And, don't hesitate to suggest a school or organization in your community that may want to learn more about bees and beekeeping.

story:
Short Summary

I am a Norwegian woman who has always loved reading! Having grown up in one of the richest countries in the world, finding something to read has never been a problem with several book shops and libraries. This is not something that is available for everybody in the world.

I think reading is an essential part of a good education as it will make you discover new worlds and I think the more you read the more you want to learn about people of the world. It is also a great way to escape your daily life and just dream.

That is why I want to start a mobile library for the wonderful people on the island of Zanzibar. 

You know the joy of reading and can help spread that joy by donating to this project!

The total amount of 10.000 Euro would cover the purchase of a van and materials to transform it into a fun mobile library, as well as books and games and daily newspapers. You can never have enough books, games or newspapers!

If the goal is not reached, the amount will still be used towards the library by buying books and starting small with crates to bring to the schools around Stone Town, Zanzibar.

Education is the most important weapon for peace. To get to know different people and different cultures through reading, the world will not seem so scary anymore. To learn what is happening in the world and be able to do something about it. This is the way to show the world that reading can change a person!

I have volunteered on Zanzibar and in other African countries and I have seen the smiles on the children when they were given a book to read or just by reading for them. Last year I bought English school reading books for one school on Zanzibar. They now have the opportunity to read in class and also to borrow the books and read at home. The head master told me the pupils had been so happy and wanted to borrow the books straight away.

Of course there is always a risk that a new project will not succeed but in my view, when it comes to children and reading, you can never go wrong! I have incredibly hard working and serious partners on Zanzibar and this project has a very good chance of succeeding and hopefully spreading to other parts of Zanzibar and other countries.
    If you are unable to contribute economically, please share this campaign with your friends via the Indiegogo share tools as that will most certainly be a good help for my campaign and for the children of Zanzibar.

    Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Are you already wondering where 'Upkwa' is located on the world map and who 'Akus' are? My name is Buba Sulle Dicko. I am a teacher in Government Secondary School Upkwa (GSS Upkwa), the lone secondary school with the highest enrollment of Aku students in Cameroon. There are scores of girls attending this school thereby breaking an age-old cultural barrier that relegated girls to the backyard. I am also president of Aku Cultural and Development Association (ACUDA) founded in 2008 to give a voice to this highly under served community. Aku are a pastoral community mostly found in Menchum and parts of Donga and Mantung divisions in the north west Region of Cameroon. It is a community which has just begun embracing secular education and still has the highest illiteracy level in Cameroon. They settle in remote areas grazing their cattle with little or no access to social amenities like schools, hospitals, potable water and electricity. Put together, the Aku people constitute about 40% of Menchum population (MINPLAPDAT 2001) with the lowest literacy level. Women are the worst hit and only two girls (Hadija Haruna and  Hajara) have ever reached high school in the close to 50 years history of the Aku people in Menchum.

WHERE IS UPKWA? 

Upkwa is located some 8km north of Wum town in Menchum division, North West Cameroon. It is a resettlement camp for survivors of the 1986 Lake Nyos disaster which killed closed to 2.000 people including thousands of animals and birds. After the disaster, a concentration of Aku people were resettled in Upkwa where they have taken to subsistence farming as a new way of survival. In 1992, the government built a primary school in the area to provide education for their children as a way of bringing them out of poverty. In 2011, a community effort led to the creation of a secondary school in the area (GSS Upkwa). Today, the school has a steady growing enrollment and many girls have the opportunity to attend school. About 80% of students in the school wouldn't have been in school if this school wasn't opened as the distance to the next school is too great. 

However, one of the major setbacks to effective learning in the school is the lack of electricity and computers to teach computer science. Computer science is a core subject taught in all government schools in Cameroon and taken at end of course official examination (GCE Ordinary Level). Lack of both electricity and computers deprive students of this school the ability to compete with students of other schools. Cameroon's lone electricity company, SONEL, cannot extend electricity to the area because there is no clientele. The inhabitants are poor farmers struggling to emerge from the disaster of 1986.

About 400 meters north of GSS Upkwa is the Upkwa integrated health center.This health unit serves some 3,000 people in the communities of Upkwa, Sangwa, Ngoh, Echuon and Karakara which surround Upkwa. This hospital runs on a generator to carryout diagnosis; when there is no gas available, darkness fills the center at night causing work to become difficult if not impossible. To create a solution, families bring bush lamps to look after their sick ones at night. Lack of electricity hinders work in the hospital and patients sometimes trek long distances to either Wum District Hospital or other suffering from excruciating pain along the way while others are unable to reach the hospital in time. Paying for fuel to run the generator in the health unit has remained a hurdle to the community.  

Therefore, there is a felt need to solve the energy and computer problems in both institutions which are just a few meters apart. This solution is what this project seeks to put in place with your support. Therefore, supporting this project means boosting education and health of the Aku community and bringing them out of the darkness of ignorance, illiteracy, poverty and above all rampant human rights abuses by people who have been exploited for their ignorance...

WHAT THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO DO. 

The project seeks to put in place a viable solar energy plant of 1000kw capacity to supply regular energy to both institutions. For the school this means purchasing and installing 10 computers in GSS Upkwa, one printer, one photocopier and an internet wireless network to ease learning in GSS Upkwa. Where as for the health center, lights and equipment will be available for the doctor and nurse to use during the night as well as for families as they care for their loved ones. Give jobs to engineers from the community who will then care for the solar panels.

ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS

The environmental condition of Upkwa provides a conducive environment for the effective installation and working of solar energy and wireless internet. Upkwa is an open land with no winds and less trees and much sunshine. The average temperature in Cameroon ranges from 20 C to 28 C or 72 F to 88 F preventing any concern of snow or extreme heat which is faced elsewhere in the world. It is the only way to bring development closer to the people and boost computer education in this highly needed school which is gateway for development in the Aku community.

With your support, we are sure to succeed in this project and bring the Aku community to the limelight of development.  Wouldn't  it be glorious to have your name inscribed in the niche of history as one who changed the future of a generation of suffering people? What if your name remains boldly smiling across the street from the walls of GSS Upkwa? Isn't it a rewarding idea to support an effort geared towards giving meaning to the lives of a disaster stricken people? Of course it will. So, what are you waiting for? Be the first to set the pace for a project which will open a new horizon for a people struggling to emerge from darkness. Be the FIRST candle to melt out in order to dispel darkness and lit other candles!!! 

THIS IS HOW WE INTEND TO SPEND THE MONEY YOU GIVE US

BUDGET ANALISES

Solar energy plant for both institutions:                                              $13850.00 USD

Ten computers, printer, photocopier and wireless internet

plus one computer and 14 lights:                                                              $5275.44 USD

Total Amount needed:                                                                               $19.125.44 USD

The Impact

This project will have the following impacts once completed:

1. It will boost learning in GSS Upkwa and expose the students to the global world by boosting ICT knowledge.

2. It will facilitate the already running penpal program between GSS Upkwa and Austin Prep. in the USA. This is an exchange program developed by Peace Corps Volunteer, Sean Gray where 45 students of GSS Upkwa are in exchange communication with 45 of their counterparts in Austin Prep. in America. Due to absence of energy and computers, letters of GSS Upwa students are collected by Sean Gray and me before being scanned and sent to Austin Prep. through a  link established to that effect.

3. The project will also salvage the situation of the Upkwa Integrated Health center by providing energy to run diagnosis and provide lighting to families looking after their sick ones.

4. Above all, the project will raise literacy level in the Aku community which has  the highest rate of illiteracy in north wet Cameroon.

Risks & Challenges

The lone challenge this project might face is that of insecurity of equipment during and after installation. To resolve this problem, the school and health center both have night and day guards who are in charge of security and who maintain total control and surveillance over the area.

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way you can help this project if you like it but are unable to donate is to promote the project amongst friends and well wishers. Every step taken to help will be appreciated!

BUDGET ANALISES
Solar energy plant for both institutions:                                              $13850.00 USD
Ten computers, printer, photocopier and wireless internet
plus one computer and 14 lights:                                                              $5275.44 USD

The
Impact
This project will have the following
impacts once completed: 
1. It will boost learning in GSS
Upkwa and expose the students to the global world by boosting ICT knowledge. 
2.
It will facilitate the already running penpal program between GSS Upkwa and
Austin Prep. in the USA. This is an exchange program developed by Peace Corps
Volunteer, Sean Gray where 45 students of GSS Upkwa are in exchange
communication with 45 of their counterparts in Austin Prep. in America. Due to
absence of energy and computers, letters of GSS Upwa students are collected by
Sean Gray and me before being scanned and sent to Austin Prep. through a 
link established to that effect. 
3.
The project will also salvage the situation of the Upkwa Integrated Health
center by providing energy to run diagnosis and provide lighting to families
looking after their sick ones. 
4.
Above all, the project will raise literacy level in the Aku community which has  the highest rate of illiteracy in north wet Cameroon.

& Challenges
The lone challenge this project
might face is that of insecurity of equipment during and after installation. To
resolve this problem, the school and health center both have night and day guards who
are in charge of security and who maintain total control and surveillance over
the area.

Ways You Can Help

project if you like it but are unable to donate is to promote the project
amongst friends and well wishers. Every step taken to help will be appreciated!

story:
YOU CAN STILL DONATE TO THE #BUILDCAMPAIGN!
 CLICK HERE TO LEARN HOW!

 TO JOIN OUR CHANGE A CHILD'S LIFE BY GIVING THE GIFT OF AN EDUCATION!

Team up with us to build our first primary school and roll-out a new solution to the education problem that plagues Uganda!

We are excited and eager to break ground.  The money we raise will:

 • enable us to build 2 classrooms in our 1st primary school
 • bring a new and superior educational experience to impoverished children. 

The two top-quality classrooms will be used to educate local village children ranging in ages 2-5 years old.  Our nursery, pre-k, and kindergarten classes will be offered free of charge to impoverished children living within the community.  Allowing young ones access to a top-tier educational experience during the most critical time in the development of a child's brain.  

Our state-of-the-art  school will:

  • offer free access to to nursery, pre-k, and kindergarten to village children.
  • offer over 300 scholarships per year to academically capable students.
  • create jobs.
  • improve community infrastructure (electricity, running water, and paved roads).

Join us in bringing a learning environment every child deserves to the rural villages across Africa.

WHO WE ARE:

The Shule Foundation is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit co-founded by Jacqueline Wolfson, a NYC-based entrepreneur and Okello Kelo Sam, a former child soldier and peace activist living in Uganda. Shule is dedicated to bring a top-quality learning experience to all African children for the 21st century.

The Shule Foundation not interested in just building schools. Shule (meaning “school” in Swahili) wants to promote, progress, and propagate a world-class education system in tandem with International Baccalaureate that graduates well-rounded productive global citizens. Our schools will work extensively to assimilate with the culture and customs of the areas in which we reside. The teachers will be hired locally, the curriculum will be locally tailored, and the education will be universal.

WHY SHOULD YOU CARE?

Africa is home to more than 50% of out-of-school children worldwide and 60% of these children are unemployed. Across the continent, 7 out of 10 rural youths have never attended school. In the western world every child has the right to a free education, but in developing countries education is NOT free. A lack of funds prevents over 46 million primary school age children across the continent from ever stepping foot in a school.

Now think past the immediate and look to the future.  By 2030, Africa will be home to 41% of the world’s youth population. Imagine the impact an increasingly uneducated population will have on our world.
• growing strain on the environment and on our natural resources
• increased financial burden on western countries to cover the cost of aid
• increased global instability

“There is no more powerful way to uphold the vision of a future free from conflict than by keeping schools running.” ~ Gordon Brown

WHAT DO I HAVE TO DO? 

It’s simple:  Donate and tell your friends and family about our #BuildCampaign.  By spreading the word you become eligible to join our referral campaign.  When your network donates you could possibly win a trip to Uganda or an iPad mini 3.

Here is how you can be entered to win a trip to Uganda for our 2016 Groundbreaking Ceremony:

Through our referral campaign, you can win a chance to be in Uganda alongside us for this momentous milestone.

Participating is simple:

  1. Make sure you are logged in to your IndieGoGo account.
  2. If you don't have an IndieGoGo account, go and register one by clicking here.
    When you are finished, come back to this page.
  3. At the top of this page use the share buttons to share this campaign.
    You can use the social media buttons, but also the Link button to generate your unique link that points to this page.
    We will track each time you share the campaign with these links!
  4. Important!  To qualify - your network must donate at least $150 collectively and share on social media. We must reach our fundraising goal of $250,000. 
    So spread the word as far and wide as you can so we can get started!

    Every person who clicks on your link gets you closer to being with us in Uganda!

Visit our website for more details about the trip and other ways to be entered into the drawing.  

NO QUESTION OR CONCERN WILL GO UNANSWERED!

Why the $50,000 goal?
This is NOT our real goal, of course, but we didn't want to scare you. A quality classroom can be built for $25,000, but a full service top-tier school requires a good deal more.  At the Shule Foundation, we are dedicated to building schools, not just classrooms.

Every dollar raised will go towards completing our first campus and providing every student and teacher with everything they need to succeed:

dormitories ● indoor plumbing ● electricity ● modern science and computer labs ● community library ● classrooms ● computers ● tablets ● textbooks ● internet ● infirmary ● dining hall ● teacher's salary ● teacher housing ● sports facility ● farming equipment ● livestock ● and so much more...

How much money from this campaign actually goes to build the schools?  With the exception of IndieGoGo/PayPal fees and shipping of the perks, every dollar will go to building our first school in Uganda.  If we raise more than we need for our first school, the additional funds will go to the building of our second school, as we do not plan on stopping at just one. There are too many children in sub-Saharan Africa with great potential that need access to a quality educational experience. 

Will you update me on the progress of the project?   Of course! At every stage of the building as well as when the school is opened, we will send you status updates including photos and videos.

What payment methods do you accept? We accept Pay Pal and major credit cards. If you want to pay by check just contact us directly and we will provide you with our mailing address.

Can I donate from anywhere in the world? For sure!

When will I get my gift?  If you qualified for a t-shirt you will get it once the campaign is over.  You will receive photos of your engraved brick once construction is complete.  Please make sure to let us know if you change your e-mail at anytime. We don’t want you to miss out. 

Is shipping included in the perks? Yes.

Is my contribution tax deductible? Yes.

How can I join you in Uganda for the groundbreaking ceremony? Please visit our #buildcampaign page to learn more. http://shulefoundation.org/buildcampaign/

I have another question...
Please post any questions as a comment (see the comments tab in the top menu), and we will respond as soon as we can.

story:
Hello!

My name is Jovonna Jones (Jojo), and I am the lead coordinator for The VISIONS Legacy Project, a paid  6-week summer training program where youth teach youth about social justice, community building, and artistic activism. During Legacy, our we learn valuable strategies for facilitating discussion and organizing initiatives on issues of diversity and justice in cross-cultural settings. Thus summer, our theme will be "Street Harassment," and we will focus our tools and projects on understanding/addressing the various factors that sustain the culture of street harassment in and around Boston. 
I started as one of the first participants of The Legacy Project in 2008, when I was just finishing up my freshman year of high school. We are now going on our 8TH summer. All of our facilitators started our programs over the past summers, and we want to make sure that the Legacy continues! 

Here's The Deal: 

While The Legacy Project has thrived through various grants over the past years, we still need a bit more help! In order to continuing paying and supporting our participants to keep doing this crucial work this summer, we need to raise $5,000 for: 

  • Summer Stipends -- Each participant receives $9/hr.  
  • Transportation Passes -- Reaching out to the community, networking, and outings are a huge part of our program, and train/bus rides get expensive! If we can afford a $75 MBTA Link pass for each participant, that will provide them with unlimited travel for 4 weeks of the program, giving them plenty of flexibility to pursue street team for our community event and utilize other resources for their projects.  
  • Artistic Resources -- We aim to provide resources for participants to try out different mediums for their activism: disposable cameras, paint/canvas, printing, etc. 
  • Community Event -- Our annual summer event requires funding primarily for food/drink, honorariums for guest artists, and decorations. 
  • Future Work -- VISIONS Inc. produces the YES Kit, a curriculum of youth engagement strategies for various sectors (education, healthcare, etc.) These kits cost $100 each, and  your financial support will help us purchase YES Kits for students who wish to proceed with diversity work and instiutional change during the school year. 


Your Impact

Your contribution to The Legacy Project will be so significant for so many reasons:

  • Many youth programs centered on diversity, the arts, and community organizing cannot afford to pay their participants, leaving lots of young people unable to pursue community activism as a viable employment option. By supporting The Legacy Project, you are investing in the change-makers of today and tomorrow, proving that social justice and artistic activism is valuable and possible at any age. 
  • Participants of the Legacy Project have gone on to create social justice programs at their schools, build platforms around the issues they care about through public scholarship, and create artistic works influenced by the tools they learned during the Legacy Project. 
  • VISIONS sponsors continuing Legacy Project participants to travel around the country working with VISIONS Senior Consultants on diversity and community issues concerning healthcare, business, education, and politics. 
Ultimately, your investment in The Legacy Project for ONE summer will spark a ripple effect of influence and change. You will be supporting young people to strategize effective change in our communities--personally, interpersonally, institutionally, and culturally. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Our $5,000 goal for this summer is meant to provide a more solid foundation for The Legacy Project to provide the most engaging learning space possible for our 15 participants. Here are some other ways you can help support our goal: 

  • MAKE SOME NOISE!!! Spread the word about The Legacy Project to your friends, family, colleagues--whomever will listen! In fact, you can use Indiegogo's handy online sharing tools to send that page to your networks.
  • Are you a Boston-area artist? We're looking for justice-oriented artists to perform at our community event, so you could really help us out by donating your skills at our show! Email jovojones11@gmail.com for more information. 
  • Do you have a knack for grabbing grants and raising funds? Please send us any information about local/national/global grants or funders that would be interested in our project! 


Thank you so much for taking the time out to read our page -- Stay connected to us and our work this summer by checking out our blog.

story:
Crowdsourced Scientific Research

Co-Lab hosts an open-database of scientific experiments from which users are financially incentivized to make observations, ask questions, and form hypotheses:

  • 85% of biomedical research funding is wasted due to the out-dated infrastructure of scientific research.
  • Co-Lab was founded by Patrick Joyce, a medical student at Georgetown University who left a PhD program in molecular biology because of the job market for academic researchers.
  • We want to create an open-access, transparent, and conflict-of-interest-free online marketplace for contributions to scientific research. 
    • Open-Access - All content will be published under a Creative Commons 4.0 license to increase exposure. Anyone, anywhere can learn from or contribute to Co-Lab.
    • Transparent - All of Co-Lab's proprietary and financial information will be made publicly-available. Any profit made by Co-Lab will be published for community criticism. 
    • Conflict-of-Interest-Free - We will only accept funding from community-approved sources that avoid the appearance of impropriety.

By building Co-Lab, we will create a home for research outputs that breaks down the socioeconomic barriers to participating in the scientific community and incentivizes collaborative discovery.

 

Why Co-Lab Needs Crowdsourced Funding

We're asking for your help to develop Co-Lab's fully functional platform because:

  • Our founder is a student who has developed Co-Lab's MVP using his own personal funds.
  • Crowdfunding the full platform will allow us to build Co-Lab without introducing a financial conflict-of-interest.
  • Utilizing our MVP, we will source hypotheses from our community to find the most effective way to deploy the capital we raise from this campaign - We want YOU to be involved in Co-Labs organizational decision-making!

Where Will the Funding Go?

​The funding from this campaign will go towards:

  • Optimizing and scaling Co-Lab for adoption as a collaborative tool for academic researchers who understand the value of open-science and want to share their data and involve the general public in their research workflows.
  • Designing and executing a controlled experiment to provide objective evidence for the value of crowdsourced research science.

 

The Impact of Crowdsourced Science

Using the scientific method as a format for academic debate will incentivize a more diverse, healthy, and productive scientific community:

  • Diverse - Access to a career in science for those who are currently socioeconomically excluded .
  • Healthy - Direct financial compensation of posts gets rid of the economic need for intellectual property or copyright restrictions. 
  • Productive - Observations, questions, and hypotheses are modular "micro"-research outputs that are easy for both academically trained and citizen scientists to use. The result is a financial incentive for scientific literacy among the general public.

Risks & Challenges

This will not be an easy path. There are significant hurdles along the way that we can only overcome as a united, collaborative scientific community:

  • Objectivity - The algorithms used by Co-Lab to curate and financially compensate content are incredibly important to the success of this project. In the interest of transparency and fairness we will utilize formula's derived from community-consensus designed to achieve measurable outcomes and minimize bias.
  • Adoption - Many in the scientific community have overcome incredible odds to find success in the current system and are understandably resistant to change. Co-Lab's success will be dependent on early adopters and their ability to provide objective proof of the utility of crowdsourced scientific research. 

 

What is Co-Lab's Revenue Model?

Co-Lab sources grant-funding from patrons of scientific research, collects a community-approved variable administration fee ranging from 0.1-3%, and then distributes the remainder of the capital to its users based on a social-consensus algorithm. 

Currently, funding organizations spend ~5% of their budgets administering research grants to achieve an estimated 15% return on investment. By harnessing the wisdom of the crowd, Co-Lab presents funders of scientific research with a drastically improved ROI. 

Any profit collected by Co-Lab will be published for community criticism.

 

I Have No Money to Spare, How Else Can I Help?

Donate your observations, questions, and hypotheses! We understand that many in the scientific community are over-worked and under-paid. That's why we made Co-Lab!

  • Sign-up for crowdsourced scientific research at http://www.Co-Lab.fun
  • Help spread the word about Co-Lab! Share this campaign using the social sharing buttons at the top of this page. The larger the community, the better the research!

 

Thanks for your support, we can't wait to collaborate with you!

 

 

Works Cited

-85% of biomedical research spending is wasted-http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2809%2960329-9/abstract

-Academic scientists only spend 40% of their time conducting research -https://www.nature.com/news/young-scientists-under-pressure-what-the-data-show-1.20871

-60% of STEM PhDs are unable to find academic research positions-https://www.air.org/sites/default/files/downloads/report/STEM%20nonacademic%20careers%20April14.pdf

This will not be an easy path. There are significant hurdles along the way that we can only overcome as a united, collaborative scientific community:


Objectivity - The algorithms used by Co-Lab to curate and financially compensate content are incredibly important to the success of this project. In the interest of transparency and fairness we will utilize formula's derived from community-consensus designed to achieve measurable outcomes and minimize bias.

Adoption - Many in the scientific community have overcome incredible odds to find success in the current system and are understandably resistant to change. Co-Lab's success will be dependent on early adopters and their ability to provide objective proof of the utility of crowdsourced scientific research. 


 
What is Co-Lab's Revenue Model?
Co-Lab sources grant-funding from patrons of scientific research, collects a community-approved variable administration fee ranging from 0.1-3%, and then distributes the remainder of the capital to its users based on a social-consensus algorithm. 
Currently, funding organizations spend ~5% of their budgets administering research grants to achieve an estimated 15% return on investment. By harnessing the wisdom of the crowd, Co-Lab presents funders of scientific research with a drastically improved ROI. 
Any profit collected by Co-Lab will be published for community criticism.
 
I Have No Money to Spare, How Else Can I Help?

Donate your observations, questions, and hypotheses! We understand that many in the scientific community are over-worked and under-paid. That's why we made Co-Lab!


Sign-up for crowdsourced scientific research at http://www.Co-Lab.fun


Help spread the word about Co-Lab! Share this campaign using the social sharing buttons at the top of this page. The larger the community, the better the research!

 
Thanks for your support, we can't wait to collaborate with you!  Works Cited-85% of biomedical research spending is wasted-http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2809%2960329-9/abstract-Academic scientists only spend 40% of their time conducting research -https://www.nature.com/news/young-scientists-under-pressure-what-the-data-show-1.20871-60% of STEM PhDs are unable to find academic research positions-https://www.air.org/sites/default/files/downloads/report/STEM%20nonacademic%20careers%20April14.pdf

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sultan Akif and I am the founder of ‘Library in a Week’ project (www.libraryinaweek.com). I left a successful, 17 years career, as a global executive with organizations like Microsoft and IBM to follow my dream of empowering youths. After building one of the largest youth empowerment annual events in Canada, it is now my mission to illuminate the far corners of the planet with the brilliance of knowledge; one library at a time. To give those that are left behind the tools to succeed and the power to dream. Connecting with my passion has been one of the best life decisions for me and you can read the full story here.

The mission of Library in a Week project is to make 100 libraries around the world in a way that drives real sustainable change - our project brings together the community to build the library rather than rely solely on external organizations. Our method is agile, cost effective and has a real impact! A key focus on my 17 years corporate career was to create large reusable solutions and land them globally; little did I realize that I was learning a very specific skill-set for something much bigger in life! I went to Nepal this summer to write my book on a very different topic – the transformation of my career from technology to youth empowerment. In an exciting series of events, I truly connected with my purpose and built two libraries. I libraries were completed in 4 days each in Katmandu, Nepal and Tal, Nepal. Tal in particular was a major undertaking as this remote village of 200 is deep in the Himalayas, only accessible by 5 days of walk or a treacherous 7 hours jeep ride from the nearest road. We just completed our third library in the Amazon jungle (video here https://youtu.be/ynHZOwfqKfg) and will be completing our fourth in Mexico in November.

This campaign is to raise funds to build our fifth library close to Merzouga Morocco in the Sahara Desert in December. We plan to complete the project by the first week of January.

If we are able to accumulate additional funds, they will go towards building our next library in Panama City or a similar location.

What We Need & What You Get

We have the capability to deliver these libraries very quickly. the only thing holding us back are funds. Your contributions will accelerate out ability to make an impact.

In return, you will be recognized both in the library and in the video footage that will be captured of the build. If you have a business, we can do specific shout-outs to your brand for increased market awareness.

The Impact

See the impact we have already had at www.libraryinaweek.com

story:
Support HempTour 2018 Crowdfunding Campaign

 

Hemp is by far the most versatile plant we have. If we utilise it, we can replace wood paper, GM cotton, petrochemical plastics, concrete and other toxic building materials which are destroying our environment and our health. Hemp can restore our health, the soil, the environment and the economy.

 

Hemp is not new; in fact it has been used as a crop for over 10,000 years. Unfortunately, hemp has many barriers, mainly due to it being part of the cannabis family. Hemp is non-psychoactive and has more than 25,000 commercial uses. Other strains of cannabis have been used for thousands of years as a medicine and it is time that these truths are known and utilised.

 

 

HempTank is the UK’s Hemp Education and Policy Development

Think Tank

 

We at HempTank believe that the key to creating policy development is education, not only passing our extensive knowledge of the hemp industry to the Government so that they can make informed opinions based on facts and scientific data, it is equally important to pass this information onto the people of Britain so that we can all understand the huge benefits and be involved in this process. These policy developments will affect us all in many positive ways so it is only right that the people have the power to create change.

 

 

Education Leads to Demand and Demand Leads to Supply

 

With your support, we will design and construct a portable hemp maze which will educate the public on the history, uses and the benefits to all of us with a future hemp industry. We will tour the UK and each event will include not only the hemp maze but also talks, live music, demonstrations and some other surprises. This tour will increase awareness and open up new markets and opportunities in this field. We also intend to take the HempTour to Westminster and the European Parliament in Brussels.

 

 

Together we can break through the current barriers and develop a green industrial revolution.

 

Now is the time to replace unsustainable materials with sustainable plant based products. Hemp plastics were being developed a century ago and hemp paper, clothing, food and even buildings have a long history. What would the world be like now had we not stopped using hemp 80 years ago?

 

If today is a typical day on planet Earth, we will lose 116 square miles of rainforest, or about an acre a second. We will lose another 72 square miles to encroaching deserts, as a result of human mismanagement and overpopulation. We will lose 40 to 100 species, and no one knows whether the number is 40 or 100. Today the human population will increase by 250,000. Tonight the Earth will be a little hotter; it's waters more acidic, and the fabric of life more threadbare. Today oil is becoming scarcer and our carbon footprint is far too high. (Paul Benhaim)

 

Hemp is by far the most valuable industrial crop we have and by switching to hemp, we can help towards many of the world’s problems:

 

  • One of the most important discoveries in the biology of all vertebrates was the discovery of the Endocannabinoid System (ECS). The ECS, discovered over a quarter of a century ago, is fundamental to our health. Through education and policy development, together we can break down the many inherent barriers to this industry.
  • Hemp yields 4 times the output of trees for paper. Nobody likes deforestation; we can stop over 40% of this destruction by switching to hemp paper. Prior to the late 1800’s, all paper was derived from hemp.
  • Hemp bio-plastic can replace petrochemical plastics; it is carbon negative, biodegradable and compostable unlike fossil fuel versions we currently use which break down and bio-accumulate in the food chain and the oceans.
  • Hemp can replace most fossil fuel products from fuel and lubricants to paints and varnishes.
  • Hemp clothes are 4 times stronger than cotton. Most cotton is GM, growing it uses 25% of the world’s agricultural water and huge amounts of pesticides and herbicides which poison the soil. Hemp requires none of this; it can be grown organically on marginal land, it accumulates minerals in the soil and it breaks up the soil pan and so restores the soil.
  • Hempcrete can be used as a replacement for concrete. It is carbon negative compared to concrete which releases 1.5 tons of CO2 per ton.
  • Hemp insulation can replace poisonous asbestos / plastic products.
  • Hemp seeds and oil contain omegas 3, 6 and 9 essential & non essential fatty acids and produces more easily absorbed protein than any other crop.
  • Hemp reforestation on marginal land with bio-char production can draw down carbon from the atmosphere.
  • Hemp can be used for bio-remediation as it absorbs toxins, heavy metals and even radiation from the soil. Hemp was grown on a massive scale following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster for this reason.
  • Although we do not support the recreational cannabis movement, we do support the access and availability of regulated medicinal cannabis for those whose lives can be dramatically improved.

 

 

Your donations will help to revitalise the hemp industry here in the UK which will ultimately benefit us all. Please donate today and make HempTour 2018 a reality.

Together we can do this!

 

Thank you!

 

 

For more information, please visit: www.HempTank.co.uk and follow us on Facebook to have your say. Visit HempTour 2018 when we are in your area (Free Entry).
